titleStmt.title: Chavez Ravine:From a Home to Home Plate
titleStmt.author: S. Gao
L. Zezza
J. Sotelo

bibl.title: Name of the archival collection, Institution

div.p: In 1959 in a hilly alcove known as Chavez Ravine, the construction of today’s Los Angeles landmark, Dodger Stadium, began. That same year, a little girl and resident of the ravine, was photographed standing on her family’s property. Features contorted, she holds a sign of protest that reads, “Can you buy three lots and two houses for $10,000”, which directly addresses the city of Los Angeles. Compositionally, the image not only documents a time and place, but also functions as an artistic statement: captured directly in the center of the Polaroid frame, the little girl becomes both a literal central figure, and a figurative heroine in the battle for her community lost to corporate modernization.

Walt Disney altered visitors’ perceptions and attitudes so they might believe Disneyland was a new reality. Disney chose Anaheim as the location for his future park, almost an hour outside of Los Angeles. Anaheim’s setting was not urban, but it was close to the population center of L.A. to attract visitors. Disney’s plan included one main entrance that directs everyone onto Main Street, U.S.A. From there, guests divided into Adventureland, Frontierland, Fantasyland, or Tomorrowland. Many critics thought Disney’s plan was impractical and inefficient; however, Disney disagreed. Disney viewed Main Street as a place for first impressions, designed to create special ambiance; therefore, it was critically important that all guests view the same landscape upon entry to the park. Instead of focusing on Main Street as a money-earner, Disney concentrated on developing sensory experiences. Main Street served “as the gateway to Disneyland’s virtual reality” as guests would “walk through a tunnel and emerge in another world (Dehrer 38-9).
